body:
I can reproduce this for a paused folder, but not in the normal non-paused case. My steps to reproduce:

- Have a folder
- Pause it
- Shut down syncthing
- Delete the folder from disk
- Start syncthing
- Directory is recreated (folder still looks paused)
- Resume folder (it gets stopped due to missing marker)

Without the pausing I get the expected 

```
[MRIW7] 10:30:12 WARNING: Error on folder default: folder path missing
[MRIW7] 10:30:12 INFO: Failed initial scan of readwrite folder default
```

on startup.

This is a "recursion" from #4094 #4095 . In quotation marks because creating the root directory when adding a folder, regardless of whether it is paused or not, was done on purpose in the context of creating ignore patterns on a new/paused folder. The right thing to do is probably to create the root dir only when there is any kind of interaction with it (starting, editing ignore patterns, more?).

What we used to do was create missing directories when starting/adding a folder *if the index for it is empty*. That should still be the case imho, paused or not. I suspect that the paused case just skips that check.

We still do that, but paused folders are neither added nor started in the model, but skipped in `CommitConfiguration`. That's where I added the creation of the folder root, such that `SetIgnores` doesn't fail. I'll propose a PR shortly  that removes that and checks the folder path in `SetIgnores` (when I have written tests for this and the old issue).

issue.title: lib/model: Don't create folder root when paused (fixes #4903)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
### Purpose

Since #4095 folder roots are created for paused folders, which isn't desirable (#4903) - don't do that anymore. To keep the ability to set ignore patterns on paused folders (#4094), check and create the folder root when setting ignore patterns. Folder marker wasn't touched before and isn't touched now, so that safety mechanism wasn't/isn't jeopardized.

### Testing

Add tests for both #4903 and #4094.

body: This only happens if the directory never had any files, once it has some files it will stop trying to create the directory. .stfolder is not a file in this context

I am still experiencing this issue on the same device with the updated Syncthing and macOS versions below. Is there anything I can provide to help getting to the bottom of this?

#### Version Information
Syncthing Version: v0.14.48, macOS (64 bit)
OS Version: macOS High Sierra 10.13.5 (17F77)

Example #2 in the original issue (I have not tested #1 since I upgraded to v0.14.48).

Syncthing tries to create directories for paused folders when those directories were on external drives that are no longer mounted.
Example 2 talks about directories inside a folder, so I find it hard to believe that happens on paused folders.

The test case for this issue is failing on OpenBSD and Syncthing 0.14.50:
[test.log](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/2441392/test.log)

```
--- FAIL: TestIssue4903 (0.00s)
    model_test.go:3760: expected path missing error, got: <nil>
```

Full test log attached.
Given it's different users replying I am not sure if this answers the question correctly.

Apologies for the confusion, @AudriusButkevicius, I'm working on this with @vext01. His response in a separate issue (5077) made this detail clear. I was just "cross-posting" to help out.

And now that 0.14.51 has been released, we'll be retesting with that.
Looking at the logs it seems that inotify on bsd has issues, yet I suspect this is not related to this issue, so let's stop polluting here and move over to #5077

(#5077 is for a different test failure)

Here's some more info on this.

 * This test only fails when the test suite is run as a whole.

```
fremen% STRACE=model go test -v -run TestIssue4903
=== RUN   TestIssue4903
2018/10/07 12:49:55.767658 model.go:2688: INFO: Paused folder folder1
2018/10/07 12:49:55.768013 folderconfiguration.go:99: INFO: bug: uncached filesystem call (should only happen in tests)
2018/10/07 12:49:55.768077 folderconfiguration.go:99: INFO: bug: uncached filesystem call (should only happen in tests)
--- PASS: TestIssue4903 (0.01s)
PASS
```

```
$ go run build.go test
...
--- FAIL: TestIssue4903 (0.00s)
```

 * I can only reproduce this failure on one of my two OpenBSD machines. They are both running the same version of go (1.11) and they both are using syncthing `f528923d1ef224a07d58fea21b0dca14ca18ba78`.

Odd.. Maybe a race? (Note that I can't use `-race` on OpenBSD).

> Looking at the logs it seems that inotify on bsd has issues

I don't think OpenBSD has inotify(7) by the way.

When we say inotify, we mean the functionality, not the implementation. I suspect it would be using kqueue on bsd. Anyways, I don't have a bsd machine to test this. Perhaps there is some some test that leaves something behind that causes other tests to fail. I guess logs would be useful but given they are convoluted it might be hard to understand what happens. You could also binary search if some subset of tests cause this issue.

> When we say inotify, we mean the functionality, not the implementation. I suspect it would be using kqueue on bsd.

Ah I see. OpenBSD certainly has kqueue.
